          V-230300 - RHEL 8 must prevent files with the setuid and setgid bit set from being executed on the /boot directory.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230300r743959_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010571
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The "nosuid" mount option causes the system not to execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "nosuid" option on the /boot directory.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:162
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010571 - RHEL 8 must prevent files with the setuid and setgid bit set from being executed on the /boot directory.
          Description:The "nosuid" mount option causes the system not to execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (If /boot is mounted, it is mounted with the nosuid option)
              • false (If /boot is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the nosuid option)
            • false (/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg exists.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16200 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:If /boot is mounted, it is mounted with the nosuid option
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16200 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/boot'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:32800 (partition_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'nosuid'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • mount_point equals '/boot'
          • device equals '/dev/nvme0n1p1'
          • uuid equals 'b9b47763-4f7d-4c46-9e6a-64643b7c4f17'
          • fs_type equals 'xfs'
          • mount_options equals 'rw'
          • mount_options equals 'relatime'
          • mount_options equals 'seclabel'
          • mount_options equals 'attr2'
          • mount_options equals 'inode64'
          • mount_options equals 'logbufs=8'
          • mount_options equals 'logbsize=32k'
          • mount_options equals 'noquota'
          • mount_options equals '4096'
          • total_space equals '75432'
          • space_used equals '50822'
          • space_left equals '24610'
          • space_left_for_unprivileged_users equals '24610'
          • block_size equals '4096'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          mount_options
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16201 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:If /boot is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the nosuid option
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16201 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/boot\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:34001 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?:^nosuid$|^nosuid,|,nosuid$|,nosuid,)'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/fstab'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'fstab'
          • pattern equals '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/boot\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'UUID=b9b47763-4f7d-4c46-9e6a-64643b7c4f17 /boot xfs defaults 0 0'
          • line equals 'UUID=b9b47763-4f7d-4c46-9e6a-64643b7c4f17 /boot xfs defaults 0 0'
          • subexpression equals 'defaults'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:10602 (file_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg exists.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:10602 (file_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/boot/efi/EFI/redhat/grub.cfg'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230301 - RHEL 8 must prevent special devices on non-root local partitions.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230301r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010580
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. The only legitimate location for device files is the /dev directory located on the root partition. false
          Fix Text:Configure the "/etc/fstab" to use the "nodev" option on all non-root local partitions.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:163
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010580 - RHEL 8 must prevent special devices on non-root local partitions.
          Description:The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. The only legitimate location for device files is the /dev directory located on the root partition.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Device files are mounted with the nodev option. Mounts on '/' are ignored.)
            • true (Device files are configured in /etc/fstab to use the nodev option. Mounts on '/' are ignored.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16300 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Device files are mounted with the nodev option. Mounts on '/' are ignored.
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16300 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must match the pattern '^/\S+$'
          Include Items If:
          • device matches the pattern '^/dev\S*$'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:32700 (partition_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'nodev'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]

          V-230311 - RHEL 8 must disable the kernel.core_pattern.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230311r858769_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010671
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to disable storing core dumps.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          kernel.core_pattern = |/bin/false

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          The system configuration files need to be reloaded for the changes to take effect. To reload the contents of the files, run the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:168
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010671 - RHEL 8 must disable the kernel.core_pattern.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (kernel.core_pattern setting in kernel is set to '|/bin/false'.)
            • false (kernel.core_pattern setting is set to '|/bin/false'., and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)

          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:16800 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must match the pattern '^\|\s*/bin/false\s*$'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]

          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16801 (textfilecontent54_test)

          • Collect any available items.

          V-230313 - RHEL 8 must disable core dumps for all users.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230313r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010673
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable core dumps for all users.

          Add the following line to the top of the /etc/security/limits.conf or in a ".conf" file defined in /etc/security/limits.d/:

          * hard core 0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921

          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:169
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010673 - RHEL 8 must disable core dumps for all users.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems.

          V-230314 - RHEL 8 must disable storing core dumps.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230314r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010674
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          A core dump includes a memory image taken at the time the operating system terminates an application. The memory image could contain sensitive data and is generally useful only for developers trying to debug problems. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable storing core dumps for all users.

          V-230315 - RHEL 8 must disable core dump backtraces.

          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives.           V-230330 - RHEL 8 must not allow users to override SSH environment variables.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230330r877377_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010830
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: SSH environment options potentially allow users to bypass access restriction in some configurations. false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to allow the SSH daemon to not allow unattended or automatic logon to the system.

          Add or edit the following line in the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file:

          PermitUserEnvironment no

          The SSH daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect. To restart the SSH daemon, run the following command:

          $ sudo systemctl restart sshd.service
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:

          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)PermitUserEnvironment(?-i)\s+(\w+)\s*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:17900 (textfilecontent54_state)

          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'no'

          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          V-230333 - RHEL 8 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230333r743966_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020011
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In RHEL 8.2 the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the pam_faillock.so module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.

          Add/Modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          deny = 3
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:181
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020011 - RHEL 8 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur.
          Description:In RHEL 8.2 the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the pam_faillock.so module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be also re-enabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (The RHEL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.)
            • false (check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the deny setting value)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:18106 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The RHEL 8 version is 8.2 or greater.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:10000 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc'
          • filename must be equal to 'os-release'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:redhat:enterprise_linux:8\.(\d+)\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:18101 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '2'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:18107 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:check /etc/security/faillock.conf for the deny setting value
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:18106 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/security/faillock.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*deny\s*=\s*([\d]+)\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:18100 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '3'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:18102 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230335 - RHEL 8 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230335r743969_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020013
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In RHEL 8.2 the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the pam_faillock.so module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000021-GPOS-00005, SRG-OS-000329-GPOS-00128 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur in 15 minutes.

          Add/Modify the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file to match the following line:

          fail_interval = 900
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:183
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020013 - RHEL 8 must automatically lock an account when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.
          Description:By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In RHEL 8.2 the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the pam_faillock.so module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.
          Class:compliance

          V-230337 - RHEL 8 must automatically lock an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail

          V-230345 - RHEL 8 must include root when automatically locking an account until the locked account is released by an administrator when three unsuccessful logon attempts occur during a 15-minute time period.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230345r743984_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020023
          Identities:CCI-000044 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-7 a)
          Description: By limiting the number of failed logon attempts, the risk of unauthorized system access via user password guessing, otherwise known as brute-force attacks, is reduced. Limits are imposed by locking the account.

          In RHEL 8.2 the "/etc/security/faillock.conf" file was incorporated to centralize the configuration of the pam_faillock.so module. Also introduced is a "local_users_only" option that will only track failed user authentication attempts for local users in /etc/passwd and ignore centralized (AD, IdM, LDAP, etc.) users to allow the centralized platform to solely manage user lockout.

          From "faillock.conf" man pages: Note that the default directory that "pam_faillock" uses is usually cleared on system boot so the access will be reenabled after system reboot. If that is undesirable a different tally directory must be set with the "dir" option.

          even_deny_root

          V-230348 - RHEL 8 must enable a user session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures for command line sessions.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230348r902725_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020040
          Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
          Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, RHEL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen. Red Hat endorses tmux as the recommended session controlling package.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enable a user to manually initiate a session lock via tmux. This configuration binds the uppercase letter "X" to manually initiate a session lock after the prefix key "Ctrl + b" has been sent. The complete key sequence is thus "Ctrl + b" then "Shift + x" to lock tmux.

          Create a global configuration file "/etc/tmux.conf" and add the following lines:

          set -g lock-command vlock
          bind X lock-session

          Reload tmux configuration to take effect. This can be performed in tmux while it is running:

          $ tmux source-file /etc/tmux.conf
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8os:def:230348
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020040 - RHEL 8 must enable a user session lock until that user re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures for command line sessions.
          Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, RHEL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen. Red Hat endorses tmux as the recommended session controlling package.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (The lock-command is set in /etc/tmux.conf)
              • false (The lock-session is bound to X, in /etc/tmux.conf)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034800 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The lock-command is set in /etc/tmux.conf
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034800 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/tmux.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*set\s+-g\s+lock-command\s+vlock\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23034801 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The lock-session is bound to X, in /etc/tmux.conf
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23034801 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/tmux.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*bind\s+X\s+lock-session\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230349 - RHEL 8 must ensure session control is automatically started at shell initialization.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230349r880737_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020041
          Identities:CCI-000056 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53A: AC-11.1 (iii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-11 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-11 b)
          Description: A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, RHEL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen. Red Hat endorses tmux as the recommended session controlling package.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000028-GPOS-00009, SRG-OS-000030-GPOS-00011 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called by adding the following lines to a custom.sh shell script in the /etc/profile.d/ directory:

          if [ "$PS1" ]; then
          parent=$(ps -o ppid= -p $$)
          name=$(ps -o comm= -p $parent)
          case "$name" in (sshd|login) tmux ;; esac
          fi

          This setting will take effect at next logon.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:194
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020041 - RHEL 8 must ensure session control is automatically started at shell initialization.
          Description:A session lock is a temporary action taken when a user stops work and moves away from the immediate physical vicinity of the information system but does not want to log out because of the temporary nature of the absence.

          The session lock is implemented at the point where session activity can be determined. Rather than be forced to wait for a period of time to expire before the user session can be locked, RHEL 8 needs to provide users with the ability to manually invoke a session lock so users can secure their session if it is necessary to temporarily vacate the immediate physical vicinity.

          Tmux is a terminal multiplexer that enables a number of terminals to be created, accessed, and controlled from a single screen. Red Hat endorses tmux as the recommended session controlling package.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/profile.d/*.sh contains a shell script to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called.)
            • false (The tmux process is running.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:19400 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/profile.d/*.sh contains a shell script to initialize the tmux terminal multiplexer as each shell is called.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:19400 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/profile.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '\.sh$'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*if\s+\[\s*"\$PS1"\s*\];\s+then\s+parent=\$\(ps\s+-o\s+ppid=\s+-p\s+\$\$\)\s+name=\$\(ps\s+-o\s+comm=\s+-p\s+\$parent\)\s+case\s+"\$name"\s+in\s+\(sshd\|login\)\s+tmux\s+;;\s+esac\s+fi\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:19401 (process58_test)
          Result:false
          Title:The tmux process is running.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:19401 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^(/usr/bin/)?tmux\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230357 - RHEL 8 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230357r858771_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020110
          Identities:CCI-000192 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
          Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          RHEL 8 utilizes pwquality as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that in order to require uppercase characters, without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf". false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used by setting the "ucredit" option.

          Add the following line to /etc/security/pwquality.conf (or modify the line to have the required value):

          ucredit = -1

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:197
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020110 - RHEL 8 must enforce password complexity by requiring that at least one uppercase character be used.
          Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          RHEL 8 utilizes pwquality as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that in order to require uppercase characters, without degrading the "minlen" value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf".
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (at least one uppercase character is required)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:19700 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:at least one uppercase character is required
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:19702 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:19700 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Note that in order to require numeric characters, without degrading the minlen value, the credit value must be expressed as a negative number in "/etc/security/pwquality.conf". false

          V-230360 - RHEL 8 must require the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class be limited to four when passwords are changed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230360r858777_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020140
          Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
          Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxclassrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in the same class in the new password. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of the number of repeating characters of the same character class when passwords are changed by setting the "maxclassrepeat" option.

          Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" conf (or modify the line to have the required value):

          maxclassrepeat = 4

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921

          Result:false

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "maxclassrepeat" option sets the maximum number of allowed same consecutive characters in the same class in the new password.

            • false (the maximum number of repeating characters of the same character class must be limited to four when passwords are changed)

          V-230361 - RHEL 8 must require the maximum number of repeating characters be limited to three when passwords are changed.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          V-230362 - RHEL 8 must require the change of at least four character classes when passwords are changed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230362r858781_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020160
          Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
          Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "minclass" option sets the minimum number of required classes of characters for the new password (digits, uppercase, lowercase, others). false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of at least four character classes when passwords are changed by setting the "minclass" option.

          Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

          minclass = 4

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "minclass" option sets the minimum number of required classes of characters for the new password (digits, uppercase, lowercase, others).

          V-230363 - RHEL 8 must require the change of at least 8 characters when passwords are changed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230363r858783_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020170
          Identities:CCI-000195 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (b); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (b))
          Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks.

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "difok" option sets the number of characters in a password that must not be present in the old password. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to require the change of at least eight of the total number of characters when passwords are changed by setting the "difok" option.

          Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

          difok = 8

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0

          Password complexity is one factor of several that determines how long it takes to crack a password. The more complex the password, the greater the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. The "difok" option sets the number of characters in a password that must not be present in the old password.
          Class:compliance

          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (at least 8 characters must change when passwords are changed)

          V-230364 - RHEL 8 passwords must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in /etc/shadow.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230364r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020180
          Identities:CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
          Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime:

          $ sudo chage -m 1 [user]
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:204
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020180 - RHEL 8 passwords must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in /etc/shadow.
          Description:Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Root does not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank)
            • false (Non-system users do not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:20400 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Root does not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:20400 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/shadow'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^root:[^:]*:[^:]*:0*:'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/shadow'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'shadow'
          • pattern equals '^root:[^:]*:[^:]*:0*:'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'root:$5$FS8s0hTWUqciRHxF$Yblb0zKNqtpPputpdQrWoB53luoGxZs3awnv5BKplp0::0:'
          • line equals 'root:$5$FS8s0hTWUqciRHxF$Yblb0zKNqtpPputpdQrWoB53luoGxZs3awnv5BKplp0::0:'
          • subexpression does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:20401 (password_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Non-system users do not have a minimum password age of 0 or blank
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:20401 (password_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • for username, at least one of the following must be true:
            • username must be equal to 'root'
            • username must be equal to 'bin'
            • username must be equal to 'daemon'
            • username must be equal to 'adm'
            • username must be equal to 'lp'
            • username must be equal to 'sync'
            • username must be equal to 'shutdown'
            • username must be equal to 'halt'
            • username must be equal to 'mail'
            • username must be equal to 'operator'
            • username must be equal to 'games'
            • username must be equal to 'ftp'
            • username must be equal to 'nobody'
            • username must be equal to 'dbus'
            • username must be equal to 'systemd-coredump'
            • username must be equal to 'systemd-resolve'
            • username must be equal to 'tss'
            • username must be equal to 'polkitd'
            • username must be equal to 'geoclue'
            • username must be equal to 'unbound'
            • username must be equal to 'gluster'
            • username must be equal to 'rtkit'
            • username must be equal to 'pipewire'
            • username must be equal to 'pulse'
            • username must be equal to 'qemu'
            • username must be equal to 'clevis'
            • username must be equal to 'usbmuxd'
            • username must be equal to 'rpc'
            • username must be equal to 'chrony'
            • username must be equal to 'avahi'
            • username must be equal to 'setroubleshoot'
            • username must be equal to 'saslauth'
            • username must be equal to 'libstoragemgmt'
            • username must be equal to 'dnsmasq'
            • username must be equal to 'sssd'
            • username must be equal to 'cockpit-ws'
            • username must be equal to 'cockpit-wsinstance'
            • username must be equal to 'colord'
            • username must be equal to 'rpcuser'
            • username must be equal to 'abrt'
            • username must be equal to 'flatpak'
            • username must be equal to 'gdm'
            • username must be equal to 'gnome-initial-setup'
            • username must be equal to 'sshd'
            • username must be equal to 'tcpdump'
            • username must be equal to 'toast'
          Exclude Items If:
          • user_id is less than '1000'
          Exclude Items If:
          • for check = 'all', user_id, all of the following must be true:
            • user_id equals '65534'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • username equals 'toast'
          • password equals [MASKED PASSWORD FIELD]
          • user_id equals '1000'
          • group_id equals '1000'
          • gcos equals 'RHEL 8.8'
          • home_dir equals '/home/toast'
          • login_shell equals '/bin/bash'
          • last_login equals '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230365 - RHEL 8 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in /etc/login.defs.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230365r858727_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020190
          Identities:CCI-000198 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to enforce 24 hours/1 day as the minimum password lifetime.

          Add the following line in "/etc/login.defs" (or modify the line to have the required value):

          PASS_MIN_DAYS 1
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:205
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020190 - RHEL 8 passwords for new users or password changes must have a 24 hours/1 day minimum password lifetime restriction in /etc/logins.def.
          Description:Enforcing a minimum password lifetime helps to prevent repeated password changes to defeat the password reuse or history enforcement requirement. If users are allowed to immediately and continually change their password, the password could be repeatedly changed in a short period of time to defeat the organization's policy regarding password reuse.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/login.defs:PASS_MIN_DAYS >= 1)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:20500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/login.defs:PASS_MIN_DAYS >= 1
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:20500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d*)'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:20500 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'login.defs'
          • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MIN_DAYS\s+(\d*)'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
          • line equals 'PASS_MIN_DAYS 0'
          • subexpression equals '0'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression

          V-230366 - RHEL 8 user account passwords must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230366r646878_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020200
          Identities:CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If RHEL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that RHEL 8 passwords could be compromised. false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime.

          Add, or modify the following line in the "/etc/login.defs" file:

          PASS_MAX_DAYS 60
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:206
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020200 - RHEL 8 user account passwords must have a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.
          Description:Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If RHEL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that RHEL 8 passwords could be compromised.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (0 -lt /etc/login.defs:PASS_MAX_DAYS -le 60)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:20600 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:0 -lt /etc/login.defs:PASS_MAX_DAYS -le 60
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:20600 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/login.defs'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*PASS_MAX_DAYS\s+(\d*)'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:20600 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:20601 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '60'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/login.defs'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'login.defs'
          • pattern equals '^\s*PASS_MAX_DAYS\s+(\d*)'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999'
          • line equals 'PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999'
          • subexpression equals '99999'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression

          V-230367 - RHEL 8 user account passwords must be configured so that existing passwords are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230367r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020210
          Identities:CCI-000199 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (d); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (d))
          Description: Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If RHEL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that RHEL 8 passwords could be compromised. false
          Fix Text:Configure non-compliant accounts to enforce a 60-day maximum password lifetime restriction.

          $ sudo chage -M 60 [user]
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:207
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020210 - RHEL 8 user account passwords must be configured so that existing passwords are restricted to a 60-day maximum lifetime.
          Description:Any password, no matter how complex, can eventually be cracked. Therefore, passwords need to be changed periodically. If RHEL 8 does not limit the lifetime of passwords and force users to change their passwords, there is the risk that RHEL 8 passwords could be compromised.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (No password in /etc/shadow has a maximum password age of 0 or greater than 60)
            • false (Root password in /etc/shadow does not have a maximum password age of 0 or greater than 60)
            • true (Non-system users do not have a blank entry in /etc/shadow for maximum password age)
            • true (Root does not have a blank entry in /etc/shadow for maximum password age)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:20700 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:No password in /etc/shadow has a maximum password age of 0 or greater than 60
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:20700 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/shadow'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:(\d+):'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Exclude Items If:
          • for check = 'all', text, at least one of the following must be true:
            • text matches the pattern '^abrt'
            • text matches the pattern '^adm'
            • text matches the pattern '^avahi'
            • text matches the pattern '^bin'
            • text matches the pattern '^chrony'
            • text matches the pattern '^clevis'
            • text matches the pattern '^cockpit-ws'
            • text matches the pattern '^cockpit-wsinstance'
            • text matches the pattern '^colord'
            • text matches the pattern '^daemon'
            • text matches the pattern '^dbus'
            • text matches the pattern '^dnsmasq'
            • text matches the pattern '^flatpak'
            • text matches the pattern '^ftp'
            • text matches the pattern '^games'
            • text matches the pattern '^gdm'
            • text matches the pattern '^geoclue'
            • text matches the pattern '^gluster'
            • text matches the pattern '^gnome-initial-setup'
            • text matches the pattern '^halt'
            • text matches the pattern '^libstoragemgmt'
            • text matches the pattern '^lp'
            • text matches the pattern '^mail'
            • text matches the pattern '^operator'
            • text matches the pattern '^pipewire'
            • text matches the pattern '^polkitd'
            • text matches the pattern '^pulse'
            • text matches the pattern '^qemu'
            • text matches the pattern '^root'
            • text matches the pattern '^rpc'
            • text matches the pattern '^rpcuser'
            • text matches the pattern '^rtkit'
            • text matches the pattern '^saslauth'
            • text matches the pattern '^setroubleshoot'
            • text matches the pattern '^shutdown'
            • text matches the pattern '^sshd'
            • text matches the pattern '^sssd'
            • text matches the pattern '^sync'
            • text matches the pattern '^systemd-coredump'
            • text matches the pattern '^systemd-resolve'
            • text matches the pattern '^tcpdump'
            • text matches the pattern '^tss'
            • text matches the pattern '^unbound'
            • text matches the pattern '^usbmuxd'
          Exclude Items If:
          • text matches the pattern '^nobody'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:20700 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than '0'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:20701 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '60'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/shadow'
          • path equals '/etc'
          • filename equals 'shadow'
          • pattern equals '^[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:(\d+):'
          • instance equals '15'
          • text equals 'toast:$5$FS8s0hTWUqciRHxF$Yblb0zKNqtpPputpdQrWoB53luoGxZs3awnv5BKplp0:19612:0:99999:'
          • line equals 'toast:$5$FS8s0hTWUqciRHxF$Yblb0zKNqtpPputpdQrWoB53luoGxZs3awnv5BKplp0:19612:0:99999:'
          • subexpression equals '99999'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:20701 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Root password in /etc/shadow does not have a maximum password age of 0 or greater than 60
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          State Operator:All item-state comparisons must be true.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:20702 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/shadow'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^root:[^:]*:[^:]*:[^:]*:(\d+):'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:20701 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be less than or equal to '60'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]

          V-230368 - RHEL 8 must be configured in the password-auth file to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230368r902759_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020220
          Identities:CCI-000200 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (e); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (v); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (e))
          Description: Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. If the information system or application allows the user to reuse their password consecutively when that password has exceeded its defined lifetime, the end result is a password that is not changed per policy requirements.

          RHEL 8 uses "pwhistory" consecutively as a mechanism to prohibit password reuse. This is set in both:
          /etc/pam.d/password-auth
          /etc/pam.d/system-auth.

          Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system in the password-auth file to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.

          Add the following line in "/etc/pam.d/password-auth" (or modify the line to have the required value):

          password requisite pam_pwhistory.so use_authtok remember=5 retry=3
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8os:def:230368
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020220 - RHEL 8 must be configured in the password-auth file to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of five generations.
          Description:Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. If the information system or application allows the user to reuse their password consecutively when that password has exceeded its defined lifetime, the end result is a password that is not changed per policy requirements.

          RHEL 8 uses "pwhistory" consecutively as a mechanism to prohibit password reuse. This is set in both:
          /etc/pam.d/password-auth
          /etc/pam.d/system-auth.

          Note that manual changes to the listed files may be overwritten by the "authselect" program.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (/etc/pam.d/password-auth: pam_pwhistory.so has remember set to 5 or greater)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23036800 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/pam.d/password-auth: pam_pwhistory.so has remember set to 5 or greater
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23036800 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/password-auth'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*password\s+(?:required|requisite)\s+pam_pwhistory\.so\s+[^#\n]*\bremember=(\d+)\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:23036800 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '5'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230369 - RHEL 8 passwords must have a minimum of 15 characters.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230369r858785_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020230
          Identities:CCI-000205 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (i); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
          Description: The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to increase exponentially the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Configurations are set in the "etc/security/pwquality.conf" file.

          The "minlen", sometimes noted as minimum length, acts as a "score" of complexity based on the credit components of the "pwquality" module. By setting the credit components to a negative value, not only will those components be required, they will not count towards the total "score" of "minlen". This will enable "minlen" to require a 15-character minimum.

          The DoD minimum password requirement is 15 characters. false
          Fix Text:Configure operating system to enforce a minimum 15-character password length.

          Add the following line to "/etc/security/pwquality.conf" (or modify the line to have the required value):

          minlen = 15

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above value.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:209
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020230 - RHEL 8 passwords must have a minimum of 15 characters.
          Description:The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to increase exponentially the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

          RHEL 8 utilizes "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. Configurations are set in the "etc/security/pwquality.conf" file.

          The "minlen", sometimes noted as minimum length, acts as a "score" of complexity based on the credit components of the "pwquality" module. By setting the credit components to a negative value, not only will those components be required, they will not count towards the total "score" of "minlen". This will enable "minlen" to require a 15-character minimum.

          The DoD minimum password requirement is 15 characters.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (passwords must have a minimum of 15 characters)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:20900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:passwords must have a minimum of 15 characters
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:20902 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:20900 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '15'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230370 - RHEL 8 passwords for new users must have a minimum of 15 characters.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230370r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020231
          Identities:CCI-000205 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-5 (1) (a); NIST SP 800-53A: IA-5 (1).1 (i); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-5 (1) (a))
          Description: The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to increase exponentially the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

          The DoD minimum password requirement is 15 characters. false
          Fix Text:Configure operating system to enforce a minimum 15-character password length for new user accounts.

          Add, or modify the following line in the "/etc/login.defs" file:

          PASS_MIN_LEN 15
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:210
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020231 - RHEL 8 passwords for new users must have a minimum of 15 characters.
          Description:The shorter the password, the lower the number of possible combinations that need to be tested before the password is compromised.

          Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. Password length is one factor of several that helps to determine strength and how long it takes to crack a password. Use of more characters in a password helps to increase exponentially the time and/or resources required to compromise the password.

          The DoD minimum password requirement is 15 characters.
          Class:compliance

          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/login.defs: PASS_MIN_LEN = 15 or greater)
