          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230431 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of userhelper in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230431r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030315
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.

          At a minimum, the organization must audit the full-text recording of privileged commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise. The "userhelper" command is not intended to be run interactively. "Userhelper" provides a basic interface to change a user's password, gecos information, and shell. The main difference between this program and its traditional equivalents (passwd, chfn, chsh) is that prompts are written to standard out to make it easy for a graphical user interface wrapper to interface to it as a child process.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful uses of the "userhelper" by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/userhelper -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-unix-update

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:264
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030315 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of userhelper in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.

          At a minimum, the organization must audit the full-text recording of privileged commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise. The "userhelper" command is not intended to be run interactively. "Userhelper" provides a basic interface to change a user's password, gecos information, and shell. The main difference between this program and its traditional equivalents (passwd, chfn, chsh) is that prompts are written to standard out to make it easy for a graphical user interface wrapper to interface to it as a child process.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/userhelper)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:26400 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/userhelper
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:26400 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/sbin/userhelper\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^/sbin/auditd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • command_line equals '/sbin/auditd'
          • exec_time equals '00:00:00'
          • pid equals '904'
          • ppid equals '1'
          • priority equals '16'
          • ruid equals '0'
          • scheduling_class equals 'TS'
          • start_time equals '18:52:45'
          • tty equals '?'
          • user_id equals '0'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_FSETID'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_RAW'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_LOCK'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_OWNER'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RAWIO'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_CHROOT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_PTRACE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_PACCT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_BOOT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_NICE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RESOURCE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_TIME'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_TTY_CONFIG'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MKNOD'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_LEASE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_WRITE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_CONTROL'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETFCAP'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MAC_OVERRIDE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MAC_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYSLOG'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_WAKE_ALARM'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_BLOCK_SUSPEND'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_READ'
          • selinux_domain_label equals 'auditd_t'
          • session_id equals '904'
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:24400 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:true
          Title:package audit is installed
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:24400 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'audit'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'audit'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '4.el8'
          • version equals '3.0.7'
          • evr equals '0:3.0.7-4.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230432 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of setsebool in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230432r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030316
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.

          At a minimum, the organization must audit the full-text recording of privileged commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise. The "setsebool" command sets the current state of a particular SELinux boolean or a list of booleans to a given value.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful uses of the "setsebool" by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/setsebool -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-unix-update

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:265
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030316 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of setsebool in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.

          At a minimum, the organization must audit the full-text recording of privileged commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise. The "setsebool" command sets the current state of a particular SELinux boolean or a list of booleans to a given value.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/setsebool)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:26500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/setsebool
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:26500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/sbin/setsebool\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^/sbin/auditd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • command_line equals '/sbin/auditd'
          • exec_time equals '00:00:00'
          • pid equals '904'
          • ppid equals '1'
          • priority equals '16'
          • ruid equals '0'
          • scheduling_class equals 'TS'
          • start_time equals '18:52:45'
          • tty equals '?'
          • user_id equals '0'
          • loginuid equals '4294967295'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_CHOWN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_FOWNER'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_FSETID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_KILL'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETGID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETUID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETPCAP'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_LINUX_IMMUTABLE'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_PACCT'

          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          [ not evaluated ]

          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230433 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of unix_chkpwd in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230433r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030317
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.

          At a minimum, the organization must audit the full-text recording of privileged commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise. The "unix_chkpwd" command is a helper program for the pam_unix module that verifies the password of the current user. It also checks password and account expiration dates in shadow. It is not intended to be run directly from the command line and logs a security violation if done so.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful uses of the "unix_chkpwd" by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/unix_chkpwd -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-unix-update

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:266
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030317 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of unix_chkpwd in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Reconstruction of harmful events or forensic analysis is not possible if audit records do not contain enough information.

          At a minimum, the organization must audit the full-text recording of privileged commands. The organization must maintain audit trails in sufficient detail to reconstruct events to determine the cause and impact of compromise. The "unix_chkpwd" command is a helper program for the pam_unix module that verifies the password of the current user. It also checks password and account expiration dates in shadow. It is not intended to be run directly from the command line and logs a security violation if done so.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/unix_chkpwd)

              • true (check for running auditd)

          Result:false

          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:26600 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/sbin/unix_chkpwd\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)

          V-230434 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the ssh-keysign in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230434r744002_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030320
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "ssh-keysign" program is an SSH helper program for host-based authentication.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "ssh-keysign" by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/libexec/openssh/ssh-keysign -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-ssh

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:267
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030320 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the ssh-keysign in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "ssh-keysign" program is an SSH helper program for host-based authentication.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          • name must be equal to 'audit'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'audit'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '4.el8'
          • version equals '3.0.7'
          • evr equals '0:3.0.7-4.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230435 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the setfacl command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230435r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030330
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "setfacl" command is used to set file access control lists.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "setfacl" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/setfacl -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:268
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030330 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the setfacl command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "setfacl" command is used to set file access control lists.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/setfacl)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:26800 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/setfacl
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:26800 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/setfacl\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^/sbin/auditd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'

          V-230436 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the pam_timestamp_check command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230436r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030340
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "pam_timestamp_check" command is used to check if the default timestamp is valid.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful uses of the "pam_timestamp_check" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/pam_timestamp_check -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-pam_timestamp_check

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:269
          Result:false

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "pam_timestamp_check" command is used to check if the default timestamp is valid.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          V-230437 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the newgrp command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230437r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030350
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "newgrp" command is used to change the current group ID during a login session.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "newgrp" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/newgrp -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k priv_cmd

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:270
          Result:false

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1".           • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230438 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the init_module and finit_module system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230438r810464_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030360
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "init_module" and "finit_module" system calls are used to load a kernel module.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "init_module" and "finit_module" system calls by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S init_module,finit_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng
          -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S init_module,finit_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:271
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030360 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the init_module and finit_module command system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "init_module" and "finit_module" command system calls is are used to load a kernel module.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of init_module syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of init_module syscall)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of finit_module syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of finit_module syscall)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:27100 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of init_module syscall
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:27100 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:.*(-S\s+init_module\s+|(\s+|,)init_module(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:27101 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false

          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:27101 (textfilecontent54_object)

          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b64\s+(?:.*(-S\s+finit_module\s+|(\s+|,)finit_module(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'

          V-230439 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the rename, unlink, rmdir, renameat, and unlinkat system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230439r810465_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030361
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "rename" system call will rename the specified files by replacing the first occurrence of expression in their name by replacement.

          The "unlink" system call deletes a name from the filesystem. If that name was the last link to a file and no processes have the file open, the file is deleted and the space it was using is made available for reuse.
          The "rmdir" system call removes empty directories.
          The "renameat" system call renames a file, moving it between directories if required.
          The "unlinkat" system call operates in exactly the same way as either "unlink" or "rmdir" except for the differences described in the manual page.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. Performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "rename", "unlink", "rmdir", "renameat", and "unlinkat" system calls by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S rename,unlink,rmdir,renameat,unlinkat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k delete
          -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S rename,unlink,rmdir,renameat,unlinkat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k delete

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:272
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030361 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the rename, unlink, rmdir, renameat and unlinkat commandsystem calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "rename" command system call will rename the specified files by replacing the first occurrence of expression in their name by replacement.
          The "unlink" system call deletes a name from the filesystem. If that name was the last link to a file and no processes have the file open, the file is deleted and the space it was using is made available for reuse.
          The "rmdir" system call removes empty directories.
          The "renameat" system call renames a file, moving it between directories if required.
          The "unlinkat" system call operates in exactly the same way as either "unlink" or "rmdir" except for the differences described in the manual page.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
          Class:compliance

          • false (All child checks must be true.)

            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of unlink)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of unlink)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of unlinkat)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of unlinkat)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETPCAP'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_BIND_SERVICE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_BROADCAST'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_RAW'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_LOCK'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_OWNER'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RAWIO'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_CHROOT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_PTRACE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_PACCT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_BOOT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_NICE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RESOURCE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_TIME'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_TTY_CONFIG'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MKNOD'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_LEASE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_WRITE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_CONTROL'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETFCAP'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MAC_OVERRIDE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MAC_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYSLOG'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_WAKE_ALARM'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_BLOCK_SUSPEND'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_READ'
          • selinux_domain_label equals 'auditd_t'
          • session_id equals '904'
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:24400 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:true
          Title:package audit is installed
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:24400 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'audit'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'audit'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '4.el8'
          • version equals '3.0.7'
          • evr equals '0:3.0.7-4.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230444 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the gpasswd command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230444r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030370
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "gpasswd" command is used to administer /etc/group and /etc/gshadow. Every group can have administrators, members and a password.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful uses of the "gpasswd" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/gpasswd -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-gpasswd

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:277
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030370 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the gpasswd command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "gpasswd" command is used to administer /etc/group and /etc/gshadow. Every group can have administrators, members and a password.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/gpasswd)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:27700 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/gpasswd
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:27700 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/gpasswd\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^/sbin/auditd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • command_line equals '/sbin/auditd'
          • exec_time equals '00:00:00'
          • pid equals '904'
          • ppid equals '1'
          • priority equals '16'
          • ruid equals '0'
          • scheduling_class equals 'TS'
          • start_time equals '18:52:45'
          • tty equals '?'
          • user_id equals '0'
          • loginuid equals '4294967295'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_CHOWN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_FOWNER'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_FSETID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_KILL'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETGID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETUID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETPCAP'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_LINUX_IMMUTABLE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_BIND_SERVICE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_BROADCAST'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_RAW'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_LOCK'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_OWNER'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RAWIO'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_CHROOT'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_CONTROL'

          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230446 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the delete_module command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230446r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030390
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "delete_module" command is used to unload a kernel module.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "delete_module" command by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S delete_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng
          -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S delete_module -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k module_chng

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:279
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030390 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the delete_module command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "delete_module" command is used to unload a kernel module.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of delete_module syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of delete_module syscall)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:27900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of delete_module syscall
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:27900 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:.*(-S\s+delete_module\s+|(\s+|,)delete_module(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:27901 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 64-bit invocations of delete_module syscall
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:27901 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b64\s+(?:.*(-S\s+delete_module\s+|(\s+|,)delete_module(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          V-230447 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the crontab command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230447r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030400
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "crontab" command is used to maintain crontab files for individual users. Crontab is the program used to install, remove, or list the tables used to drive the cron daemon. This is similar to the task scheduler used in other operating systems.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful uses of the "crontab" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/crontab -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-crontab

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:280
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030400 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the crontab command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "crontab" command is used to maintain crontab files for individual users. Crontab is the program used to install, remove, or list the tables used to drive the cron daemon. This is similar to the task scheduler used in other operating systems.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:28000 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/crontab\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)

          • command_line must match the pattern '^/sbin/auditd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • command_line equals '/sbin/auditd'
          • exec_time equals '00:00:00'
          • pid equals '904'
          • ppid equals '1'
          • priority equals '16'
          • ruid equals '0'
          • scheduling_class equals 'TS'
          • start_time equals '18:52:45'
          • tty equals '?'
          • user_id equals '0'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RAWIO'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_CHROOT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_PTRACE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_PACCT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_BOOT'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_NICE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RESOURCE'

          • selinux_domain_label equals 'auditd_t'
          • session_id equals '904'
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:24400 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:true
          Title:package audit is installed
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:24400 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'audit'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'audit'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '4.el8'
          • version equals '3.0.7'
          • evr equals '0:3.0.7-4.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230448 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chsh command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230448r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030410
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chsh" command is used to change the login shell.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "chsh" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/chsh -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k priv_cmd

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:281
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030410 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chsh command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chsh" command is used to change the login shell.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/chsh)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:28100 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/chsh
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:28100 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/chsh\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.

          • scheduling_class equals 'TS'
          • start_time equals '18:52:45'
          • tty equals '?'

          V-230449 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the truncate, ftruncate, creat, open, openat, and open_by_handle_at system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230449r810455_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030420
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "truncate" and "ftruncate" functions are used to truncate a file to a specified length.

          The "creat" system call is used to open and possibly create a file or device.
          The "open" system call opens a file specified by a pathname. If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally be created by "open".
          The "openat" system call opens a file specified by a relative pathname.
          The "name_to_handle_at" and "open_by_handle_at" system calls split the functionality of "openat" into two parts: "name_to_handle_at" returns an opaque handle that corresponds to a specified file; "open_by_handle_at" opens the file corresponding to a handle returned by a previous call to "name_to_handle_at" and returns an open file descriptor.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "truncate", "ftruncate", "creat", "open", "openat", and "open_by_handle_at" system calls by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EPERM -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access
          -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EPERM -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access

          -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EACCES -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access
          -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S truncate,ftruncate,creat,open,openat,open_by_handle_at -F exit=-EACCES -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_access

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:282
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030420 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the truncate, ftruncate, creat, open, openat, and open_by_handle_at system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "truncate" and "ftruncate" functions are used to truncate a file to a specified length.
          The "creat" system call is used to open and possibly create a file or device.
          The "open" system call opens a file specified by a pathname. If the specified file does not exist, it may optionally be created by "open".
          The "openat" system call opens a file specified by a relative pathname.
          The "name_to_handle_at" and "open_by_handle_at" system calls split the functionality of openat into two parts: "name_to_handle_at" returns an opaque handle that corresponds to a specified file; "open_by_handle_at" opens the file corresponding to a handle returned by a previous call to "name_to_handle_at" and returns an open file descriptor.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of truncate syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of truncate syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of truncate syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of truncate syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of openat syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of openat syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of openat syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of openat syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of open_by_handle_at syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of ftruncate syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of ftruncate syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of ftruncate syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of ftruncate syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of creat syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of creat syscall with exit EPERM)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of creat syscall with exit EACCES)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of creat syscall with exit EACCES)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:28200 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of truncate syscall with exit EPERM
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:28200 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:.*(-S\s+truncate\s+|(\s+|,)truncate(\s+|,))).*-F\s+exit=-EPERM\s+-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:28201 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false

          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b64\s+(?:.*(-S\s+truncate\s+|(\s+|,)truncate(\s+|,))).*-F\s+exit=-EPERM\s+-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
