          • name must be equal to 'audit'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'audit'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '4.el8'
          • version equals '3.0.7'
          • evr equals '0:3.0.7-4.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230455 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chown, fchown, fchownat, and lchown system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230455r810459_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030480
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chown" command is used to change file owner and group.

          The "fchown" system call is used to change the ownership of a file referred to by the open file descriptor.
          The "fchownat" system call is used to change ownership of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.
          The "lchown" system call is used to change the ownership of the file specified by a path, which does not dereference symbolic links.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. The performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "chown", "fchown", "fchownat", and "lchown" system calls by adding or updating the following line to "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

          -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod
          -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chown,fchown,fchownat,lchown -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:288
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030480 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chown, fchown, fchownat and lchown system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).
          The "chown" command is used to change file owner and group.
          The "fchown" system call is used to change the ownership of a file referred to by the open file descriptor.
          The "fchownat" system call is used to change ownership of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.
          The "lchown" system call is used to change the ownership of the file specified by a path, which does not dereference symbolic links.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of chown syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of chown syscall)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of lchown syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of lchown syscall)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchownat syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchownat syscall)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchown syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchown syscall)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:28800 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of chown syscall
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:28800 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:.*(-S\s+chown\s+|(\s+|,)chown(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:28801 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 64-bit invocations of chown syscall
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:28801 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b64\s+(?:.*(-S\s+chown\s+|(\s+|,)chown(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:29000 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of lchown syscall
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:29000 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:.*(-S\s+lchown\s+|(\s+|,)lchown(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230456 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chmod, fchmod, and fchmodat system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230456r810462_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030490
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chmod" system call changes the file mode bits of each given file according to mode, which can be either a symbolic representation of changes to make, or an octal number representing the bit pattern for the new mode bits.

          The "fchmod" system call is used to change permissions of a file.
          The "fchmodat" system call is used to change permissions of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall made by all programs on the system. Therefore, it is very important to use syscall rules only when absolutely necessary since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. Performance can be helped, however, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000064-GPOS-00033, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "chmod", "fchmod", and "fchmodat" syscalls by adding or updating the following line to "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

          -a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod
          -a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S chmod,fchmod,fchmodat -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:289
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030490 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chmod, fchmod and fchmodat system calls in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).
          The "chmod" command system call changes the file mode bits of each given file according to mode, which can be either a symbolic representation of changes to make, or an octal number representing the bit pattern for the new mode bits.
          The "fchmod" system call is used to change permissions of a file.
          The "fchmodat" system call is used to change permissions of a file relative to a directory file descriptor.
          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          The system call rules are loaded into a matching engine that intercepts each syscall that all programs on the system makes. Therefore, it is very important to only use syscall rules when you have to since these affect performance. The more rules, the bigger the performance hit. You can help the performance, though, by combining syscalls into one rule whenever possible.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of chmod syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of chmod syscall)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchmodat syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchmodat syscall)
            • false (Audit 32-bit invocations of fchmod syscall)
            • false (Audit 64-bit invocations of fchmod syscall)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:28900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit 32-bit invocations of chmod syscall
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:28900 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+arch=b32\s+(?:.*(-S\s+chmod\s+|(\s+|,)chmod(\s+|,))).*-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)[-\w]+)*\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:28901 (textfilecontent54_test)

          V-230462 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the sudo command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230462r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030550
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "sudo" command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user, as specified by the security policy.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "sudo" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/sudo -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k priv_cmd

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:295
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030550 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the sudo command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "sudo" command allows a permitted user to execute a command as the superuser or another user, as specified by the security policy.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/sudo)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:29500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/sudo
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:29500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/sudo\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^/sbin/auditd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • command_line equals '/sbin/auditd'
          • exec_time equals '00:00:00'
          • pid equals '904'
          • ppid equals '1'
          • priority equals '16'
          • ruid equals '0'
          • scheduling_class equals 'TS'
          • start_time equals '18:52:45'
          • tty equals '?'
          • user_id equals '0'
          • loginuid equals '4294967295'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_CHOWN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_FOWNER'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_FSETID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_KILL'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETGID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETUID'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETPCAP'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_LINUX_IMMUTABLE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_BIND_SERVICE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_BROADCAST'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_NET_RAW'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_LOCK'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_IPC_OWNER'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_CHROOT'

          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_RESOURCE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_TIME'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYS_TTY_CONFIG'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MKNOD'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_LEASE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_WRITE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_CONTROL'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SETFCAP'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MAC_OVERRIDE'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_MAC_ADMIN'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_SYSLOG'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_WAKE_ALARM'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_BLOCK_SUSPEND'
          • posix_capability equals 'CAP_AUDIT_READ'
          • selinux_domain_label equals 'auditd_t'
          • session_id equals '904'
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:24400 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:true
          Title:package audit is installed
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:24400 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'audit'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'audit'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '4.el8'
          • version equals '3.0.7'
          • evr equals '0:3.0.7-4.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230463 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the usermod command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230463r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030560
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "usermod" command modifies the system account files to reflect the changes that are specified on the command line.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful uses of the "usermod" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/sbin/usermod -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k privileged-usermod

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:296
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030560 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the usermod command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "usermod" command modifies the system account files to reflect the changes that are specified on the command line.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/usermod)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:29600 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/sbin/usermod
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:29600 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/sbin/usermod\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          V-230464 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chacl command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230464r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030570
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chacl" command is used to change the access control list of a file or directory.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000466-GPOS-00210 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful use of the "chacl" command by adding or updating the following rule in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/chacl -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k perm_mod

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:297
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030570 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the chacl command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without generating audit records that are specific to the security and mission needs of the organization, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "chacl" command is used to change the access control list of a file or directory.

          When a user logs on, the AUID is set to the UID of the account that is being authenticated. Daemons are not user sessions and have the loginuid set to "-1". The AUID representation is an unsigned 32-bit integer, which equals "4294967295". The audit system interprets "-1", "4294967295", and "unset" in the same way.

          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230465 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the kmod command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230465r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030580
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "kmod" command is used to control Linux Kernel modules.

          The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

          DoD has defined the list of events for which RHEL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

          1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

          2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

          3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

          4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00216, SRG-OS-000477-GPOS-00222 false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to audit the execution of the module management program "kmod" by adding or updating the following line to "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules":

          -a always,exit -F path=/usr/bin/kmod -F perm=x -F auid>=1000 -F auid!=unset -k modules

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:298
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030580 - Successful/unsuccessful uses of the kmod command in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter). The "kmod" command is used to control Linux Kernel modules.

          The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

          DoD has defined the list of events for which RHEL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

          1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

          2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

          3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

          4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit invocations of /usr/bin/kmod)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:29800 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit invocations of /usr/bin/kmod
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:29800 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-a\s+(always,exit|exit,always)\s+-F\s+path=/usr/bin/kmod\s+(-F\s+perm=([rwa]*x[rwa]*)\s+)?-F\s+auid>=1000\s+-F\s+auid!=(4294967295|-1|unset)(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\S+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^/sbin/auditd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]

          • extended_name equals 'audit-(none):3.0.7-4.el8.x86_64'

          V-230467 - Successful/unsuccessful modifications to the lastlog file in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230467r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030600
          Identities:CCI-000169 (NIST SP 800-53: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53A: AU-12.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-12 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-12 a)
          Description: Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

          The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

          DoD has defined the list of events for which RHEL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

          1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

          2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

          3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

          4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000037-GPOS-00015, SRG-OS-000042-GPOS-00020, SRG-OS-000062-GPOS-00031, SRG-OS-000392-GPOS-00172, SRG-OS-000462-GPOS-00206, SRG-OS-000471-GPOS-00215, SRG-OS-000473-GPOS-00218 false
          Fix Text:Configure the audit system to generate an audit event for any successful/unsuccessful modifications to the "lastlog" file by adding or updating the following rules in the "/etc/audit/rules.d/audit.rules" file:

          -w /var/log/lastlog -p wa -k logins

          The audit daemon must be restarted for the changes to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:299
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030600 - Successful/unsuccessful modifications to the lastlog file in RHEL 8 must generate an audit record.
          Description:Without the capability to generate audit records, it would be difficult to establish, correlate, and investigate the events relating to an incident or identify those responsible for one.

          Audit records can be generated from various components within the information system (e.g., module or policy filter).

          The list of audited events is the set of events for which audits are to be generated. This set of events is typically a subset of the list of all events for which the system is capable of generating audit records.

          DoD has defined the list of events for which RHEL 8 will provide an audit record generation capability as the following:

          1) Successful and unsuccessful attempts to access, modify, or delete privileges, security objects, security levels, or categories of information (e.g., classification levels);

          2) Access actions, such as successful and unsuccessful logon attempts, privileged activities or other system-level access, starting and ending time for user access to the system, concurrent logons from different workstations, successful and unsuccessful accesses to objects, all program initiations, and all direct access to the information system;

          3) All account creations, modifications, disabling, and terminations; and

          4) All kernel module load, unload, and restart actions.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Audit modifications to /var/log/lastlog)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (check for running auditd)
              • true (All child checks must be true.)
                • true (package audit is installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:29900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Audit modifications to /var/log/lastlog
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:29900 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/audit.rules'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*-w\s+/var/log/lastlog(\s+-p\s*([rx]*w[rx]*a[rx]*|[rx]*a[rx]*w[rx]*))?(\s+(-k\s+|-F\s+key=)\w+)?\s*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:16000 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:check for running auditd
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:16000 (process58_object)

          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:

          V-230483 - RHEL 8 must take action when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230483r877389_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-030730
          Identities:CCI-001855 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AU-5 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AU-5 (1))
          Description: If security personnel are not notified immediately when storage volume reaches 75 percent utilization, they are unable to plan for audit record storage capacity expansion. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to initiate an action to notify the SA and ISSO (at a minimum) when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity by adding/modifying the following line in the /etc/audit/auditd.conf file.

          space_left = 25%

          Note: Option names and values in the auditd.conf file are case insensitive.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:309
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-030730 - RHEL 8 must take action when allocated audit record storage volume reaches 75 percent of the repository maximum audit record storage capacity.
          Description:If security personnel are not notified immediately when storage volume reaches 75 percent utilization, they are unable to plan for audit record storage capacity expansion.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/audit/auditd.conf: space_left = 25%)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:30900 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/audit/auditd.conf: space_left = 25%
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:30900 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
          • pattern must match the pattern '(?i)^\s*space_left\s*=\s*([%\d]+)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:30900 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '25%'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/audit/auditd.conf'
          • path equals '/etc/audit'
          • filename equals 'auditd.conf'
          • pattern equals '(?i)^\s*space_left\s*=\s*([%\d]+)\s*(?:#.*)?$'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'space_left = 75'
          • line equals 'space_left = 75'
          • subexpression equals '75'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression

          V-230488 - RHEL 8 must not have any automated bug reporting tools installed.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230488r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040001
          Identities:CCI-000381 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-7; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 a)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

          Examples of non-essential capabilities include, but are not limited to, games, software packages, tools, and demonstration software not related to requirements or providing a wide array of functionality not required for every mission, but which cannot be disabled.

          Verify the operating system is configured to disable non-essential capabilities. The most secure way of ensuring a non-essential capability is disabled is to not have the capability installed. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable non-essential capabilities by removing automated bug reporting packages from the system with the following command:

          $ sudo yum remove abrt*
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:313
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040001 - RHEL 8 must not have any automated bug reporting tools installed.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

          Examples of non-essential capabilities include, but are not limited to, games, software packages, tools, and demonstration software not related to requirements or providing a wide array of functionality not required for every mission, but which cannot be disabled.

          Verify the operating system is configured to disable non-essential capabilities. The most secure way of ensuring a non-essential capability is disabled is to not have the capability installed.
          Class:compliance

          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (The package abrt and any related packages are NOT installed)

          V-230503 - RHEL 8 must be configured to disable USB mass storage.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230503r809319_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040080
          Identities:CCI-000778 (NIST SP 800-53: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53A: IA-3.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-3; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: IA-3)
          Description: USB mass storage permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000114-GPOS-00059, SRG-OS-000378-GPOS-00163 false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the ability to use the USB Storage kernel module and the ability to use USB mass storage devices.

          Add or update the following lines in the file "/etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf":

          install usb-storage /bin/true
          blacklist usb-storage

          Reboot the system for the settings to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:325
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040080 - RHEL 8 must be configured to disable USB mass storage.
          Description:USB mass storage permits easy introduction of unknown devices, thereby facilitating malicious activity.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'install usb-storage /bin/true')
            • false (/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'blacklist usb-storage')
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'install usb-storage /bin/true'
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:32500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '.*'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*install[ \t]+usb-storage[ \t]+/bin/true[ \t]*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32501 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'blacklist usb-storage'
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:32501 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '.*'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*blacklist[ \t]+usb-storage[ \t]*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230507 - RHEL 8 Bluetooth must be disabled.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230507r833336_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040111
          Identities:CCI-001443 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-18 (1); NIST SP 800-53A: AC-18 (1).1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-18 (1); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-18 (1))
          Description: Without protection of communications with wireless peripherals, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and either read, altered, or used to compromise the RHEL 8 operating system.

          This requirement applies to wireless peripheral technologies (e.g., wireless mice, keyboards, displays, etc.) used with RHEL 8 systems. Wireless peripherals (e.g., Wi-Fi/Bluetooth/IR Keyboards, Mice, and Pointing Devices and Near Field Communications [NFC]) present a unique challenge by creating an open, unsecured port on a computer. Wireless peripherals must meet DoD requirements for wireless data transmission and be approved for use by the Authorizing Official (AO). Even though some wireless peripherals, such as mice and pointing devices, do not ordinarily carry information that need to be protected, modification of communications with these wireless peripherals may be used to compromise the RHEL 8 operating system. Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification.

          Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of communications with wireless peripherals can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical barriers to wireless radio frequencies) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, then logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa. If the wireless peripheral is only passing telemetry data, encryption of the data may not be required. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to disable the Bluetooth adapter when not in use.

          Build or modify the "/etc/modprobe.d/bluetooth.conf" file with the following line:

          install bluetooth /bin/true

          Disable the ability to use the Bluetooth kernel module.

          $ sudo vi /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.conf

          Add or update the line:

          blacklist bluetooth

          Reboot the system for the settings to take effect.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:326
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040111 - RHEL 8 Bluetooth must be disabled.
          Description:Without protection of communications with wireless peripherals, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and either read, altered, or used to compromise the RHEL 8 operating system.

          This requirement applies to wireless peripheral technologies (e.g., wireless mice, keyboards, displays, etc.) used with RHEL 8 systems. Wireless peripherals (e.g., Wi-Fi/Bluetooth/IR Keyboards, Mice, and Pointing Devices and Near Field Communications [NFC]) present a unique challenge by creating an open, unsecured port on a computer. Wireless peripherals must meet DoD requirements for wireless data transmission and be approved for use by the Authorizing Official (AO). Even though some wireless peripherals, such as mice and pointing devices, do not ordinarily carry information that need to be protected, modification of communications with these wireless peripherals may be used to compromise the RHEL 8 operating system. Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification.

          Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of communications with wireless peripherals can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical barriers to wireless radio frequencies) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, then logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa. If the wireless peripheral is only passing telemetry data, encryption of the data may not be required.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'install bluetooth /bin/true')
            • false (/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'blacklist bluetooth')
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32600 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'install bluetooth /bin/true'
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:32600 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '.*'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*install[ \t]+bluetooth[ \t]+/bin/true[ \t]*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32601 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/modprobe.d contains a file that contains 'blacklist bluetooth'
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:32601 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/modprobe.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '.*'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*blacklist[ \t]+bluetooth[ \t]*$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230510 - RHEL 8 must mount /dev/shm with the noexec option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230510r854051_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040122
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
          Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system so that /dev/shm is mounted with the "noexec" option by adding /modifying the /etc/fstab with the following line:

          tmpfs /dev/shm tmpfs defaults,nodev,nosuid,noexec 0 0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:329
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040122 - RHEL 8 must mount /dev/shm with the noexec option.
          Description:The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (If /dev/shm is mounted, it is mounted with the noexec option)
            • true (If /dev/shm is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the noexec option)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32900 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:If /dev/shm is mounted, it is mounted with the noexec option
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:32700 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/dev/shm'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:32900 (partition_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'noexec'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • Message - 'device'
          • mount_point equals '/dev/shm'
          • device equals 'tmpfs'
          • uuid does not exist
          • fs_type equals 'tmpfs'
          • mount_options equals 'rw'
          • mount_options equals 'nosuid'
          • mount_options equals 'nodev'
          • mount_options equals 'seclabel'
          • mount_options equals '6'
          • total_space equals '223648'
          • space_used equals '0'
          • space_left equals '223648'
          • space_left_for_unprivileged_users equals '223648'
          • block_size equals '4096'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          mount_options
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32901 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:true
          Title:If /dev/shm is configured in /etc/fstab, it is configured with the noexec option
          Check Existence:Zero or more collected items may exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:32701 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/dev/shm\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:34101 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '(?:^noexec$|^noexec,|,noexec$|,noexec,)'

          V-230511 - RHEL 8 must mount /tmp with the nodev option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230511r854052_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040123
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
          Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system so that /tmp is mounted with the "nodev" option by adding /modifying the /etc/fstab with the following line:

          /dev/mapper/rhel-tmp /tmp xfs defaults,nodev,nosuid,noexec 0 0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:330
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040123 - RHEL 8 must mount /tmp with the nodev option.
          Description:The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/tmp is mounted with the nodev option)
            • false (/tmp is configured with the nodev option in /etc/fstab)
            • false (/tmp is configured in /etc/fstab)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33000 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/tmp is mounted with the nodev option
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:15800 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/tmp'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:32700 (partition_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'nodev'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • mount_point does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33001 (variable_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/tmp is configured with the nodev option in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33000 (variable_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • var_ref must be equal to 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33000'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:33000 (variable_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to 'nodev'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • var_ref equals 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33000'
          • value equals ''
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33002 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/tmp is configured in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33001 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/tmp\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230512 - RHEL 8 must mount /tmp with the nosuid option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230512r854053_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040124
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
          Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false

          V-230513 - RHEL 8 must mount /tmp with the noexec option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230513r854054_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040125
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
