          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33000 (variable_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • var_ref must be equal to 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33000'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:33200 (variable_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to 'noexec'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • var_ref equals 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33000'
          • value equals ''
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33002 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/tmp is configured in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33001 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/tmp\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230514 - RHEL 8 must mount /var/log with the nodev option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230514r854055_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040126
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
          Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system so that /var/log is mounted with the "nodev" option by adding /modifying the /etc/fstab with the following line:

          /dev/mapper/rhel-var-log /var/log xfs defaults,nodev,nosuid,noexec 0 0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:333
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040126 - RHEL 8 must mount /var/log with the nodev option.
          Description:The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/var/log is mounted with the nodev option)
            • false (/var/log is configured with the nodev option in /etc/fstab)
            • false (/var/log is configured in /etc/fstab)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33300 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/var/log is mounted with the nodev option
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:15600 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/var/log'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:32700 (partition_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'nodev'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • mount_point does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33301 (variable_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/var/log is configured with the nodev option in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33301 (variable_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • var_ref must be equal to 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33300'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:33000 (variable_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to 'nodev'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • var_ref equals 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33300'
          • value equals ''
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33302 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/var/log is configured in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33302 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/var/log\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230515 - RHEL 8 must mount /var/log with the nosuid option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230515r854056_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040127
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
          Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system so that /var/log is mounted with the "nosuid" option by adding /modifying the /etc/fstab with the following line:

          /dev/mapper/rhel-var-log /var/log xfs defaults,nodev,nosuid,noexec 0 0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921

          Result:false

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          V-230517 - RHEL 8 must mount /var/log/audit with the nodev option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230517r854058_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040129
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
          Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system so that /var/log/audit is mounted with the "nodev" option by adding /modifying the /etc/fstab with the following line:

          /dev/mapper/rhel-var-log-audit /var/log/audit xfs defaults,nodev,nosuid,noexec 0 0

          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33701 (variable_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/var/log/audit is configured with the nosuid option in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33601 (variable_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • var_ref must be equal to 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33600'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:33100 (variable_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to 'nosuid'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • var_ref equals 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33600'
          • value equals ''

          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33602 (textfilecontent54_test)

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33602 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/var/log/audit\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230519 - RHEL 8 must mount /var/log/audit with the noexec option.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230519r854060_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040131
          Identities:CCI-001764 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 (2))
          Description: The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access. false
          Fix Text:Configure the system so that /var/log/audit is mounted with the "noexec" option by adding /modifying the /etc/fstab with the following line:

          /dev/mapper/rhel-var-log-audit /var/log/audit xfs defaults,nodev,nosuid,noexec 0 0
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:338
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040131 - RHEL 8 must mount /var/log/audit with the noexec option.
          Description:The organization must identify authorized software programs and permit execution of authorized software. The process used to identify software programs that are authorized to execute on organizational information systems is commonly referred to as whitelisting.

          The "noexec" mount option causes the system to not execute binary files. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved binary files, as they may be incompatible. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nodev" mount option causes the system to not interpret character or block special devices. Executing character or block special devices from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.

          The "nosuid" mount option causes the system to not execute "setuid" and "setgid" files with owner privileges. This option must be used for mounting any file system not containing approved "setuid" and "setguid" files. Executing files from untrusted file systems increases the opportunity for unprivileged users to attain unauthorized administrative access.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (/var/log/audit is mounted with the noexec option)
            • false (/var/log/audit is configured with the noexec option in /etc/fstab)
            • false (/var/log/audit is configured in /etc/fstab)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33800 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/var/log/audit is mounted with the noexec option
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33600 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/var/log/audit'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:32900 (partition_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', mount_options must be equal to 'noexec'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • mount_point does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33801 (variable_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/var/log/audit is configured with the noexec option in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33601 (variable_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • var_ref must be equal to 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33600'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:33200 (variable_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to 'noexec'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • var_ref equals 'oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:var:33600'
          • value equals ''
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:33602 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/var/log/audit is configured in /etc/fstab
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:33602 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*[^#\s]+\s+/var/log/audit\s+\S+\s+(\S+)\s+\S+\s+\S+\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230527 - RHEL 8 must force a frequent session key renegotiation for SSH connections to the server.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230527r877398_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040161
          Identities:CCI-000068 (NIST SP 800-53: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53A: AC-17 (2).1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-17 (2); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-17 (2))
          Description: Without protection of the transmitted information, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and either read or altered.

          This requirement applies to both internal and external networks and all types of information system components from which information can be transmitted (e.g., servers, mobile devices, notebook computers, printers, copiers, scanners, and facsimile machines). Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification.

          Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of organizational information can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical distribution systems) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, then logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa.

          Session key regeneration limits the chances of a session key becoming compromised.

          Satisfies: SRG-OS-000033-GPOS-00014, SRG-OS-000420-GPOS-00186, SRG-OS-000424-GPOS-00188 false
          Fix Text:Configure the system to force a frequent session key renegotiation for SSH connections to the server by add or modifying the following line in the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file:

          RekeyLimit 1G 1h

          Restart the SSH daemon for the settings to take effect.

          $ sudo systemctl restart sshd.service
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:343
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL 8 must force a frequent session key renegotiation for SSH connections to the server.
          Description:Without protection of the transmitted information, confidentiality and integrity may be compromised because unprotected communications can be intercepted and either read or altered.

          This requirement applies to both internal and external networks and all types of information system components from which information can be transmitted (e.g., servers, mobile devices, notebook computers, printers, copiers, scanners, and facsimile machines). Communication paths outside the physical protection of a controlled boundary are exposed to the possibility of interception and modification.

          Protecting the confidentiality and integrity of organizational information can be accomplished by physical means (e.g., employing physical distribution systems) or by logical means (e.g., employing cryptographic techniques). If physical means of protection are employed, then logical means (cryptography) do not have to be employed, and vice versa.

          Session key regeneration limits the chances of a session key becoming compromised.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (/etc/ssh/sshd_config:RekeyLimit max data and time are greater than zero.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • true (The openssh package is installed.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:34300 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/ssh/sshd_config:RekeyLimit max data and time are greater than zero.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:34300 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)RekeyLimit\s+(?:\d+[kmg]?)\s+(?:\d+[smdhw]?)+(?-i)\s*'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:34300 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', text must match the pattern '^(?i)\s*RekeyLimit\s+[1-9][0-9]*[kmg]?\s+([1-9][0-9]*[smhdw]?)+\s*$'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9900 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:true
          Title:The openssh package is installed.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9900 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'openssh'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'openssh'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '17.el8'
          • version equals '8.0p1'
          • evr equals '0:8.0p1-17.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'openssh-(none):8.0p1-17.el8.x86_64'

          V-230535 - RHEL 8 must prevent IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230535r858793_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040210
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to prevent IPv6 ICMP redirect messages from being accepted.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects = 0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:348
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040210 - RHEL 8 must prevent Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages from being accepted.
          Description:ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 0, and nothing else)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
              • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:34802 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:34804 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:34800 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects'
          • value equals '1'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:34803 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_redirects setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 0, and nothing else
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:34807 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:34801 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9800 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9800 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:9800 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6'
          • value equals '0'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9801 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9803 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:9801 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9802 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9804 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/proc/cmdline'
          • pattern must match the pattern '\bipv6\.disable=1\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230536 - RHEL 8 must not send Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230536r858795_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040220
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology.

          There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). There is only a directive to disable sending of IPv4 redirected packets. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not allow interfaces to perform IPv4 ICMP redirects.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects=0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:349
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040220 - RHEL 8 must not send Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects.
          Description:ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology.

          There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). There is only a directive to disable sending of IPv4 redirected packets. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0)
            • false (net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 0, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:34900 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:34900 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:34900 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects'
          • value equals '1'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:34901 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.all.send_redirects setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 0, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:34903 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:34901 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230537 - RHEL 8 must not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echoes sent to a broadcast address.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230537r858797_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040230
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Responding to broadcast ICMP echoes facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.

          There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). IPv6 does not implement the same method of broadcast as IPv4. Instead, IPv6 uses multicast addressing to the all-hosts multicast group. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.
          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not respond to IPv4 ICMP echoes sent to a broadcast address.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts=1

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:350
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040230 - RHEL 8 must not respond to Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echoes sent to a broadcast address.
          Description:Responding to broadcast ICMP echoes facilitates network mapping and provides a vector for amplification attacks.

          There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). IPv6 does not implement the same method of broadcast as IPv4. Instead, IPv6 uses multicast addressing to the all-hosts multicast group. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in kernel is set to 1)
            • false (net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35000 (sysctl_test)
          Result:true
          Title:net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in kernel is set to 1
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35000 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:35000 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35001 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35003 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:35001 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230538 - RHEL 8 must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230538r858801_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040240
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not forward IPv6 source-routed packets.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route=0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:351
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040240 - RHEL 8 must not forward source-routed packets.
          Description:Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route setting in kernel is set to 0)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_source_route setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 0, and nothing else)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
              • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).

          • Collect any available items.

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.

          • pattern must match the pattern '\bipv6\.disable=1\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'

          V-230539 - RHEL 8 must not forward IPv6 source-routed packets by default.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230539r861085_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040250
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Source-routed packets allow the source of the packet to suggest that routers forward the packet along a different path than configured on the router, which can be used to bypass network security measures. This requirement applies only to the forwarding of source-routed traffic, such as when forwarding is enabled and the system is functioning as a router.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not forward IPv6 source-routed packets by default.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_source_route=0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system

          V-230540 - RHEL 8 must not enable IPv6 packet forwarding unless the system is a router.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230540r858810_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040260
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not allow IPv6 packet forwarding, unless the system is a router.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding=0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:353
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040260 - RHEL 8 must not be performing packet forwarding unless the system is a router.
          Description:Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf

          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding setting in kernel is set to 0)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.forwarding setting in the sysctl configuration files is set to 0, and nothing else)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
              • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.

          • Collect any available items.

          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9802 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9804 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/proc/cmdline'
          • pattern must match the pattern '\bipv6\.disable=1\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230541 - RHEL 8 must not accept router advertisements on all IPv6 interfaces.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230541r858812_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040261
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

          An illicit router advertisement message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not accept router advertisements on all IPv6 interfaces unless the system is a router.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra=0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:354
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040261 - RHEL 8 must not accept router advertisements on all IPv6 interfaces.
          Description:Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

          An illicit router advertisement message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra setting in kernel is set to 0)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra setting in /etc/sysctl.d/99-sysctl.conf is set to 0, and nothing else)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
              • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35400 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra setting in kernel is set to 0
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35400 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:35400 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_ra'
          • value equals '1'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35401 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35403 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:35401 (textfilecontent54_state)

          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'

          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9800 (sysctl_test)

          • value equals '0'

          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9802 (textfilecontent54_test)

          Title:ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9804 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/proc/cmdline'
          • pattern must match the pattern '\bipv6\.disable=1\b'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230542 - RHEL 8 must not accept router advertisements on all IPv6 interfaces by default.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230542r858814_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040262
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Routing protocol daemons are typically used on routers to exchange network topology information with other routers. If this software is used when not required, system network information may be unnecessarily transmitted across the network.

          An illicit router advertisement message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not accept router advertisements on all IPv6 interfaces by default unless the system is a router.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv6.conf.default.accept_ra=0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8

              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
              • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)

          V-230543 - RHEL 8 must not allow interfaces to perform Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects by default.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230543r858816_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040270
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology.

          There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). There is only a directive to disable sending of IPv4 redirected packets. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to not allow interfaces to perform Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) ICMP redirects by default.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects = 0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:356
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040270 - RHEL 8 must not allow interfaces to perform Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirects by default.
          Description:ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages contain information from the system's route table, possibly revealing portions of the network topology.

          There are notable differences between Internet Protocol version 4 (IPv4) and Internet Protocol version 6 (IPv6). There is only a directive to disable sending of IPv4 redirected packets. Refer to RFC4294 for an explanation of "IPv6 Node Requirements", which resulted in this difference between IPv4 and IPv6.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects is set to 0 in kernel)
            • false (net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects is set to 0 in the sysctl configuration files.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35600 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects is set to 0 in kernel
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35600 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:36100 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects'
          • value equals '1'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35601 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv4.conf.default.send_redirects is set to 0 in the sysctl configuration files.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35603 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:36101 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230544 - RHEL 8 must ignore IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230544r858820_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040280
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to ignore IPv6 ICMP redirect messages.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_redirects = 0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:357
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040280 - RHEL 8 must ignore IPv6 Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) redirect messages.
          Description:ICMP redirect messages are used by routers to inform hosts that a more direct route exists for a particular destination. These messages modify the host's route table and are unauthenticated. An illicit ICMP redirect message could result in a man-in-the-middle attack.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom.           /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0)
              • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_redirects setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 0, and nothing else)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (All child checks must be true.)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in kernel is set to 1)
                • false (net.ipv6.conf.all.disable_ipv6 setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else)
              • false (ipv6.disable=1 in the kernel cmdline)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35700 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_redirects setting in kernel is set to 0
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).

          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_redirects'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:35700 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '0'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.ipv6.conf.all.accept_redirects'
          • value equals '1'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35701 (textfilecontent54_test)

          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
