          V-230545 - RHEL 8 must disable access to network bpf syscall from unprivileged processes.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230545r858822_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040281
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to prevent privilege escalation thru the kernel by disabling access to the bpf syscall by adding the following line to a file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d" directory:

          kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled = 1

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          The system configuration files need to be reloaded for the changes to take effect. To reload the contents of the files, run the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:358
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040281 - RHEL 8 must disable access to network bpf syscall from unprivileged processes.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled setting in kernel is set to 1)
            • false (kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35800 (sysctl_test)
          Result:true
          Title:kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled setting in kernel is set to 1
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35800 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:35800 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:35801 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:kernel.unprivileged_bpf_disabled is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:35803 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:35801 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230546 - RHEL 8 must restrict usage of ptrace to descendant processes.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230546r858824_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040282
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to restrict usage of ptrace to descendant processes by adding the following line to a file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d" directory:

          kernel.yama.ptrace_scope = 1

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          The system configuration files need to be reloaded for the changes to take effect. To reload the contents of the files, run the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:359
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040282 - RHEL 8 must restrict usage of ptrace to descendant processes.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf

          V-230548 - RHEL 8 must disable the use of user namespaces.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230548r858828_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040284
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to disable the use of user namespaces by adding the following line to a file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d" directory:

          Note: User namespaces are used primarily for Linux containers. If containers are in use, this requirement is not applicable.

          user.max_user_namespaces = 0

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          The system configuration files need to be reloaded for the changes to take effect. To reload the contents of the files, run the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:361
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040284 - RHEL 8 must disable the use of user namespaces.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf

          V-230555 - RHEL 8 remote X connections for interactive users must be disabled unless to fulfill documented and validated mission requirements.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230555r858721_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040340
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The security risk of using X11 forwarding is that the client's X11 display server may be exposed to attack when the SSH client requests forwarding. A system administrator may have a stance in which they want to protect clients that may expose themselves to attack by unwittingly requesting X11 forwarding, which can warrant a "no" setting.

          X11 forwarding should be enabled with caution. Users with the ability to bypass file permissions on the remote host (for the user's X11 authorization database) can access the local X11 display through the forwarded connection. An attacker may then be able to perform activities such as keystroke monitoring if the ForwardX11Trusted option is also enabled.

          If X11 services are not required for the system's intended function, they should be disabled or restricted as appropriate to the systemâ€™s needs. false
          Fix Text:Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "X11Forwarding" keyword and set its value to "no" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):

          X11Forwarding no

          The SSH service must be restarted for changes to take effect:

          $ sudo systemctl restart sshd
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:364
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040340 - RHEL 8 remote X connections for interactive users must be disabled unless to fulfill documented and validated mission requirements.
          Description:The security risk of using X11 forwarding is that the client's X11 display server may be exposed to attack when the SSH client requests forwarding. A system administrator may have a stance in which they want to protect clients that may expose themselves to attack by unwittingly requesting X11 forwarding, which can warrant a ''no'' setting.
          X11 forwarding should be enabled with caution. Users with the ability to bypass file permissions on the remote host (for the user's X11 authorization database) can access the local X11 display through the forwarded connection. An attacker may then be able to perform activities such as keystroke monitoring if the ForwardX11Trusted option is also enabled.
          If X11 services are not required for the system's intended function, they should be disabled or restricted as appropriate to the system's needs.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Query the value of the X11Forwarding setting in /etc/ssh/sshd_config)
            • true (All child checks must be true.)
              • true (The openssh package is version 7.6 or greater.)
              • true (The ssh daemon is running.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:36400 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Query the value of the X11Forwarding setting in /etc/ssh/sshd_config
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:36400 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • behavior requirements:
            • ignore_case = true
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*X11Forwarding[ \t]+([^\s#]*)[ \t]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:36400 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^(no|"no")$'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • filepath equals '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • path equals '/etc/ssh'
          • filename equals 'sshd_config'
          • pattern equals '^\s*X11Forwarding[ \t]+([^\s#]*)[ \t]*(?:|(?:#.*))?$'
          • instance equals '1'
          • text equals 'X11Forwarding yes'
          • line equals 'X11Forwarding yes'
          • subexpression equals 'yes'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          subexpression
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32401 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:true
          Title:The openssh package is version 7.6 or greater.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9900 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'openssh'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:32401 (rpminfo_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', evr must be greater than or equal to '0:7.6p1-0'
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:32400 (process58_test)
          Result:true
          Title:The ssh daemon is running.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:32400 (process58_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • command_line must match the pattern '^/usr/sbin/sshd\b'
          • pid must be greater than '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • command_line equals '/usr/sbin/sshd -D -oCiphers=aes256-gcm@openssh.com,chacha20-poly1305@openssh.com,aes256-ctr,aes256-cbc,aes128-gcm@openssh.com,aes128-ctr,aes128-cbc -oMACs=hmac-sha2-256-etm@openssh.com,hmac-sha1-etm@openssh.com,umac-128-etm@openssh.com,hmac-sha2-512-etm@openssh.com,hmac-sha2-256,hmac-sha1,umac-128@openssh.com,hmac-sha2-512 -oGSSAPIKexAlgorithms=gss-curve25519-sha256-,gss-nistp256-sha256-,gss-group14-sha256-,gss-group16-sha512-,gss-gex-sha1-,gss-group14-sha1- -oKexAlgorithms=curve25519-sha256,curve25519-sha256@libssh.org,ecdh-sha2-nistp256,ecdh-sha2-nistp384,ecdh-sha2-nistp521,diffie-hellman-group-exchange-sha256,diffie-hellman-group14-sha256,diffie-hellman-group16-sha512,diffie-hellman-group18-sha512,diffie-hellman-group-exchange-sha1,diffie-hellman-group14-sha1 -oHostKeyAlgorithms=ecdsa-sha2-nistp256,ecdsa-sha2-nistp256-cert-v01@openssh.com,ecdsa-sha2-nistp384,ecdsa-sha2-nistp384-cert-v01@openssh.com,ecdsa-sha2-nistp521,ecdsa-sha2-nistp521-cert-v01@openssh.com,ssh-ed25519,ssh-ed25519-cert-v01@openssh.com,rsa-sha2-256,rsa-sha2-256-cert-v01@openssh.com,rsa-sha2-512,rsa-sha2-512-cert-v01@openssh.com,ssh-rsa,ssh-rsa-cert-v01@openssh.com -oPubkeyAcceptedKeyTypes=ecdsa-sha2-nistp256,ecdsa-sha2-nistp256-cert-v01@openssh.com,ecdsa-sha2-nistp384,ecdsa-sha2-nistp384-cert-v01@openssh.com,ecdsa-sha2-nistp521,ecdsa-sha2-nistp521-cert-v01@openssh.com,ssh-ed25519,ssh-ed25519-cert-v01@openssh.com,rsa-sha2-256,rsa-sha2-256-cert-v01@openssh.com,rsa-sha2-512,rsa-sha2-512-cert-v01@openssh.com,ssh-rsa,ssh-rsa-cert-v01@openssh.com -oCASignatureAlgorithms=ecdsa-sha2-nistp256,ecdsa-sha2-nistp384,ecdsa-sha2-nistp521,ssh-ed25519,rsa-sha2-256,rsa-sha2-512,ssh-rsa'
          • exec_time equals '00:00:00'
          • pid equals '1107'
          • ppid equals '1'
          • priority equals '20'
          • ruid equals '0'
          • scheduling_class equals 'TS'
          • start_time equals '18:52:47'
          • tty equals '?'
          • user_id equals '0'
          • loginuid equals '4294967295'

          V-230556 - The RHEL 8 SSH daemon must prevent remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230556r858723_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040341
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: When X11 forwarding is enabled, there may be additional exposure to the server and client displays if the sshd proxy display is configured to listen on the wildcard address. By default, sshd binds the forwarding server to the loopback address and sets the hostname part of the DIPSLAY environment variable to localhost. This prevents remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display. false
          Fix Text:Configure the SSH daemon to prevent remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.

          Edit the "/etc/ssh/sshd_config" file to uncomment or add the line for the "X11UseLocalhost" keyword and set its value to "yes" (this file may be named differently or be in a different location if using a version of SSH that is provided by a third-party vendor):

          X11UseLocalhost yes
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:365
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040341 - The RHEL 8 SSH daemon must prevent remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.
          Description:When X11 forwarding is enabled, there may be additional exposure to the server and client displays if the sshd proxy display is configured to listen on the wildcard address. By default, sshd binds the forwarding server to the loopback address and sets the hostname part of the DIPSLAY environment variable to localhost. This prevents remote hosts from connecting to the proxy display.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
            • false (sshd_config X11UseLocalhost is set to 2.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.) (negated)
              • true (The openssh package is installed.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:36500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:sshd_config X11UseLocalhost is set to 2.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:36500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/ssh/sshd_config'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*(?i)X11UseLocalhost(?-i)\s+"?(\S+?)"?\s*(?:#.*|$)'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:36500 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to 'yes'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:9900 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:true
          Title:The openssh package is installed.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:9900 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'openssh'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • name equals 'openssh'
          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'
          • release equals '17.el8'
          • version equals '8.0p1'
          • evr equals '0:8.0p1-17.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'openssh-(none):8.0p1-17.el8.x86_64'

          V-230559 - The gssproxy package must not be installed unless mission essential on RHEL 8.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230559r646887_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040370
          Identities:CCI-000381 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-7; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-7.1 (ii); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-7 a; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-7 a)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

          The gssproxy package is a proxy for GSS API credential handling and could expose secrets on some networks. It is not needed for normal function of the OS. false
          Fix Text:Document the gssproxy package with the ISSO as an operational requirement or remove it from the system with the following command:

          $ sudo yum remove gssproxy
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:368
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040370 - The gssproxy package must not be installed unless mission essential on RHEL 8.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

          The gssproxy package is a proxy for GSS API credential handling and could expose secrets on some networks. It is not needed for normal function of the OS.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (package gssproxy is NOT installed)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:36800 (rpminfo_test)
          Result:false
          Title:package gssproxy is NOT installed
          Check Existence:No collected items may exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:36800 (rpminfo_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'gssproxy'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]

          • arch equals 'x86_64'
          • epoch equals '(none)'

          • version equals '0.8.0'
          • evr equals '0:0.8.0-21.el8'
          • signature_keyid equals '199e2f91fd431d51'
          • extended_name equals 'gssproxy-(none):0.8.0-21.el8.x86_64'

          V-230561 - The tuned package must not be installed unless mission essential on RHEL 8.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230561r627750_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040390
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

          The tuned package contains a daemon that tunes the system settings dynamically. It does so by monitoring the usage of several system components periodically. Based on that information, components will then be put into lower or higher power savings modes to adapt to the current usage. The tuned package is not needed for normal OS operations. false
          Fix Text:Document the tuned package with the ISSO as an operational requirement or remove it from the system with the following command:

          $ sudo yum remove tuned
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:370
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040390 - The tuned package must not be installed unless mission essential on RHEL 8.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Operating systems are capable of providing a wide variety of functions and services. Some of the functions and services, provided by default, may not be necessary to support essential organizational operations (e.g., key missions, functions).

          The tuned package contains a daemon that tunes the system settings dynamically. It does so by monitoring the usage of several system components periodically. Based on that information, components will then be put into lower or higher power savings modes to adapt to the current usage. The tuned package is not needed for normal OS operations.
          Class:compliance

          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (package tuned is NOT installed)

          V-237642 - RHEL 8 must use the invoking user's password for privilege escalation when using "sudo".

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-237642r880727_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010383
          Identities:CCI-002227 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: AC-6 (5); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: AC-6 (5))
          Description: The sudoers security policy requires that users authenticate themselves before they can use sudo. When sudoers requires authentication, it validates the invoking user's credentials. If the rootpw, targetpw, or runaspw flags are defined and not disabled, by default the operating system will prompt the invoking user for the "root" user password.
          For more information on each of the listed configurations, reference the sudoers(5) manual page. false
          Fix Text:Define the following in the Defaults section of the /etc/sudoers file or a configuration file in the /etc/sudoers.d/ directory:
          Defaults !targetpw
          Defaults !rootpw
          Defaults !runaspw

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /etc/sudoers
          /etc/sudoers.d/
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:415
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010383 - RHEL 8 must use the invoking user's password for privilege escalation when using "sudo".
          Description:The sudoers security policy requires that users authenticate themselves before they can use sudo. When sudoers requires authentication, it validates the invoking user's credentials. If the rootpw, targetpw, or runaspw flags are defined and not disabled, by default the operating system will prompt the invoking user for the "root" user password.
          For more information on each of the listed configurations, reference the sudoers(5) manual page.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers)
              • false (Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (Defaults !rootpw is configured in /etc/sudoers)
              • false (Defaults !rootpw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d)
            • false (One or more child checks must be true.)
              • false (Defaults !runaspw is configured in /etc/sudoers)
              • false (Defaults !runaspw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:41500 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:41500 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/sudoers'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*Defaults\s+\!targetpw\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:41501 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Defaults !targetpw is configured in /etc/sudoers.d
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:41501 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • path must be equal to '/etc/sudoers.d'
          • filename must match the pattern '^.*$'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*Defaults\s+\!targetpw\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'

          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:41502 (textfilecontent54_test)

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:41502 (textfilecontent54_object)

          • instance must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:41503 (textfilecontent54_test)

          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:41503 (textfilecontent54_object)

          • filename must match the pattern '^.*$'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^\s*Defaults\s+\!rootpw\s*$'
          • instance must be equal to '1'

          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:41504 (textfilecontent54_test)

          V-237643 - RHEL 8 must require re-authentication when using the "sudo" command.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-237643r861088_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010384
          Identities:CCI-002038 (NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: IA-11)
          Description: Without re-authentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

          When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the organization requires the user to re-authenticate when using the "sudo" command.

          If the value is set to an integer less than 0, the user's time stamp will not expire and the user will not have to re-authenticate for privileged actions until the user's session is terminated. false
          Fix Text:Configure the "sudo" command to require re-authentication.
          Edit the /etc/sudoers file:
          $ sudo visudo

          Add or modify the following line:
          Defaults timestamp_timeout=[value]
          Note: The "[value]" must be a number that is greater than or equal to "0".

          Remove any duplicate or conflicting lines from /etc/sudoers and /etc/sudoers.d/ files.
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:416
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010384 - RHEL 8 must require re-authentication when using the "sudo" command.
          Description:Without re-authentication, users may access resources or perform tasks for which they do not have authorization.

          When operating systems provide the capability to escalate a functional capability, it is critical the organization requires the user to re-authenticate when using the "sudo" command.

          If the value is set to an integer less than 0, the user's time stamp will not expire and the user will not have to re-authenticate for privileged actions until the user's session is terminated.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (Defaults timestamp_timeout is configured in /etc/sudoers or /etc/sudoers.d.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:41600 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:Defaults timestamp_timeout is configured in /etc/sudoers or /etc/sudoers.d.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:41602 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:41600 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be greater than or equal to '0'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-244554 - RHEL 8 must enable hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter Just-in-time compiler.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-244554r858832_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-040286
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Enabling hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter (BPF) Just-in-time (JIT) compiler aids in mitigating JIT spraying attacks. Setting the value to "2" enables JIT hardening for all users.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure RHEL 8 to enable hardening for the BPF JIT compiler by adding the following line to a file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d" directory:

          net.core.bpf_jit_harden = 2

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          The system configuration files need to be reloaded for the changes to take effect. To reload the contents of the files, run the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:477
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-040286 - RHEL 8 must enable hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter Just-in-time compiler.
          Description:It is detrimental for operating systems to provide, or install by default, functionality exceeding requirements or mission objectives. These unnecessary capabilities or services are often overlooked and therefore may remain unsecured. They increase the risk to the platform by providing additional attack vectors.

          Enabling hardening for the Berkeley Packet Filter (BPF) Just-in-time (JIT) compiler aids in mitigating JIT spraying attacks. Setting the value to "2" enables JIT hardening for all users.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (net.core.bpf_jit_harden is set to 2 in kernel)
            • false (net.core.bpf_jit_harden is set to 2 in the sysctl configuration files.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:47700 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.core.bpf_jit_harden is set to 2 in kernel
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:47700 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'net.core.bpf_jit_harden'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:14400 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '2'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'net.core.bpf_jit_harden'
          • value equals '1'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:47701 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:net.core.bpf_jit_harden is set to 2 in the sysctl configuration files.
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:47703 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:14401 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '2'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-251714 - RHEL 8 systems below version 8.4 must ensure the password complexity module in the system-auth file is configured for three retries or less.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-251714r902743_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-020102
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.

          RHEL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. This is set in both:
          /etc/pam.d/password-auth
          /etc/pam.d/system-auth

          By limiting the number of attempts to meet the pwquality module complexity requirements before returning with an error, the system will audit abnormal attempts at password changes. false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to limit the "pwquality" retry option to 3.

          Add the following line to the "/etc/pam.d/system-auth" file (or modify the line to have the required value):

          password requisite pam_pwquality.so retry=3
          Severity:medium
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8os:def:251714
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-020102 - RHEL 8 systems below version 8.4 must ensure the password complexity module in the system-auth file is configured for three retries or less.
          Description:Use of a complex password helps to increase the time and resources required to compromise the password. Password complexity, or strength, is a measure of the effectiveness of a password in resisting attempts at guessing and brute-force attacks. "pwquality" enforces complex password construction configuration and has the ability to limit brute-force attacks on the system.

          RHEL 8 uses "pwquality" as a mechanism to enforce password complexity. This is set in both:
          /etc/pam.d/password-auth
          /etc/pam.d/system-auth

          By limiting the number of attempts to meet the pwquality module complexity requirements before returning with an error, the system will audit abnormal attempts at password changes.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (/etc/pam.d/system-auth:retry not greater than 3 and not 0)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:25171400 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:/etc/pam.d/system-auth:retry not greater than 3 and not 0
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:25171400 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/pam.d/system-auth'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[ \t]*password[ \t]+(?:(?:required)|(?:requisite))[ \t]+pam_pwquality\.so(?:[ \t]+|(?:[ \t][^#\r\f\n]+[ \t]+))retry=([0-9]+)(?:\s|$)'
          • instance must be equal to '1'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:ste:20000018 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must match the pattern '^[123]$'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

        Detailed Results: Low Severity (CAT III)

          V-230269 - RHEL 8 must restrict access to the kernel message buffer.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230269r858756_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010375
          Identities:CCI-001090 (NIST SP 800-53: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53A: SC-4.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-4)
          Description: Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

          This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products. This can be verified by acceptance/validation processes in DoD or other government agencies.

          There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

          Restricting access to the kernel message buffer limits access to only root. This prevents attackers from gaining additional system information as a non-privileged user.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to restrict access to the kernel message buffer.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          kernel.dmesg_restrict = 1

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:135
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010375 - RHEL 8 must restrict access to the kernel message buffer.
          Description:Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

          This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products. This can be verified by acceptance/validation processes in DoD or other government agencies.

          There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

          Restricting access to the kernel message buffer limits access to only root. This prevents attackers from gaining additional system information as a non-privileged user.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a gien filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf/usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in kernel is set to 1)
            • false (kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:13500 (sysctl_test)
          Result:false
          Title:kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in kernel is set to 1
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:13500 (sysctl_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • name must be equal to 'kernel.dmesg_restrict'
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:13500 (sysctl_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', value must be equal to '1'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ false ]
          • name equals 'kernel.dmesg_restrict'
          • value equals '0'
          Additional Information:Check requirement not met.
          value
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:tst:13501 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:kernel.dmesg_restrict setting in sysctl configuration files is set to 1, and nothing else, and there are no conflicting settings in other files
          Check Existence:One or more collected items must exist.
          Check:All collected items must match the given state(s).
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:obj:13503 (textfilecontent54_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • Collect any available items.
          State ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:ste:13501 (textfilecontent54_state)
          State Requirements:
          • check_existence = 'at_least_one_exists', subexpression must be equal to '1'
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.

          V-230270 - RHEL 8 must prevent kernel profiling by unprivileged users.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230270r858758_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010376
          Identities:CCI-001090 (NIST SP 800-53: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53A: SC-4.1; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: SC-4; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: SC-4)
          Description: Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

          This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products. This can be verified by acceptance/validation processes in DoD or other government agencies.

          There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

          Setting the kernel.perf_event_paranoid kernel parameter to "2" prevents attackers from gaining additional system information as a non-privileged user.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files. All configuration files are sorted by their filename in lexicographic order, regardless of which of the directories they reside in. If multiple files specify the same option, the entry in the file with the lexicographically latest name will take precedence. Files are read from directories in the following list from top to bottom. Once a file of a given filename is loaded, any file of the same name in subsequent directories is ignored.
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf false
          Fix Text:Configure the operating system to prevent kernel profiling by unprivileged users.

          Add or edit the following line in a system configuration file, in the "/etc/sysctl.d/" directory:

          kernel.perf_event_paranoid = 2

          Remove any configurations that conflict with the above from the following locations:
          /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/local/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf

          Load settings from all system configuration files with the following command:

          $ sudo sysctl --system
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8:def:136
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010376 - RHEL 8 must prevent kernel profiling by unprivileged users.
          Description:Preventing unauthorized information transfers mitigates the risk of information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resources have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared resources is also commonly referred to as object reuse and residual information protection.

          This requirement generally applies to the design of an information technology product, but it can also apply to the configuration of particular information system components that are, or use, such products.           There may be shared resources with configurable protections (e.g., files in storage) that may be assessed on specific information system components.

          The sysctl --system command will load settings from all system configuration files.           /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /lib/sysctl.d/*.conf
          /etc/sysctl.conf
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • true (kernel.perf_event_paranoid setting in kernel is set to 2)

          V-230292 - RHEL 8 must use a separate file system for /var.

          Rule ID:xccdf_mil.disa.stig_rule_SV-230292r902718_rule
          Test Type:Automated
          Result:Fail
          Version:RHEL-08-010540
          Identities:CCI-000366 (NIST SP 800-53: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53A: CM-6.1 (iv); NIST SP 800-53 Rev 4: CM-6 b; NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5: CM-6 b)
          Description: The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing. false
          Fix Text:Migrate the "/var" path onto a separate file system.
          Severity:low
          Weight:10.0
          Reference:
          Title:DPMS Target Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Publisher:DISA
          Type:DPMS Target
          Subject:Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8
          Identifier:2921
          Definitions:
          Definition ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.rhel8os:def:230292
          Result:false
          Title:RHEL-08-010540 - RHEL 8 must use a separate file system for /var.
          Description:The use of separate file systems for different paths can protect the system from failures resulting from a file system becoming full or failing.
          Class:compliance
          Tests:
          • false (All child checks must be true.)
            • false (All child checks must be true.)
              • false (There is a separate file system for /var.)
              • false (There is a separate file system configured for /var.)
          Tests:
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.linux:tst:23029200 (partition_test)
          Result:false
          Title:There is a separate file system for /var.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.linux:obj:23029200 (partition_object)
          Object Requirements:
          • mount_point must be equal to '/var'
          Collected Item/State Result:
          [ not evaluated ]
          • mount_point does not exist
          Additional Information:Check existence requirement not met.
          Test ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:tst:23029201 (textfilecontent54_test)
          Result:false
          Title:There is a separate file system configured for /var.
          Check Existence:All collected items must exist.
          Check:Result is based on check existence only.
          Object ID:oval:mil.disa.stig.ind:obj:23029201 (textfilecontent54_object)

          • filepath must be equal to '/etc/fstab'
          • pattern must match the pattern '^[^# \t]+\s+/var\s+'
          • instance must be greater than or equal to '1'
